scenarioDescription:
The HIP 54373 Exoplanetary System


Overview

HIP 54373 is a star with 0.57 times the mass of the Sun, and NaN times its radius. It is located 61.05 light years away from the solar system.

HIP 54373 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the HIP 54373 system


HIP 54373 b

HIP 54373 b was discovered by the Las Campanas Observatory observatory, in 2019-06, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HIP 54373 b is 8.624 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HIP 54373 b is 2.870 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, HIP 54373 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


HIP 54373 c

HIP 54373 c was discovered by the Las Campanas Observatory observatory, in 2019-06, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.10 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HIP 54373 c is 12.447 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HIP 54373 c is 3.570 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, HIP 54373 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanetary system HIP 54373, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the Las Campanas Observatory.
name: HIP 54373 - System With 2 Exoplanets
